This is a follow up of https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/49660

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): infer correct generic types for directives when so…
Issues.Body:
…me inputs are omitted

The template type-checker could inadvertently end up inferring `any` for a directive's generic type argument, effectively disabling all type checking of values of that generic type. This happened when the directive reflects the generic type in multiple inputs, some of which were not bound from the parent template. Since omitted inputs were passed into the directive's type constructor using the `0 as any` expression, TypeScript sees the input of type `any` as inference source of the generic type and locks that in.

The initial remediation idea was to remove omitted inputs from the type-constructor entirely, changing its type from `Pick<Dir, 'a'|'...'>` to `Partial<Pick<Dir, 'a'|'...'>>` to make all input bindings optional. This introduces issues where the `undefined` type that is introduced affects type inference, causing test failures.

Instead, omitted inputs are now passed into the type constructor as `never` type, which is TypeScript's bottom type such that no inference candidates are introduced.

Fixes #57644

---

This change is likely (too) breaking, as the inference of the `any` type used to effectively disable type-checking of any (pun not intended) expressions that reflect a generic type of a directive with missing inputs. `MatCalendar` is one such directive (the one reported in #57644) that has many inputs that reflect the generic type, where it is typical that not all those inputs are actually bound.

A g3 global presubmit should help determine the impact of the breakage, which may require us to introduce this behind a compiler option.

Issues.Title: Empty path breaks routing and consequently SEO in a server side rendered Angular application
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

First of all, this worked in the past, when initialNavigation: "enabled", and relativeLinkResolution was still available. Probably Angular 13, back in 2021, something like that.

After that, we updated the project a couple of times of course. Currently on Angular 17 and upgraded from nguniversal to @angular/ssr.

The problem is as follows:

We want to be able to load a specific route, say a product page, products/1. And we want to set the proper Meta and SEO information. That is the reason we are using Angular SSR in the first place.

If we load, reload or SEO verify that specific route, the page source and the SEO results show the homepage information.
When we reload the page, we can also observe, that the homepage title appears in the browser tab for a split second, before it gets replaced by the product page title.

After some testing it turns out, if we change the homepage component to use a "home" route instead of an empty " " route, the product page information loads correctly. Furthermore, if we remove `</ion-router-outlet>` (also tested with `<router-outlet></router-outlet>`), the meta information also loads corretly in the page (even though the page doesn't load of course).

We use resolvers on the homepage to fetch some data, and we have another set of resolvers for the product page.

We don't use standalone components and we don't use child modules.

Changing the order of the routes, chaining resolvers, putting the Meta service inside the resolver had no effect.

Issues.Title: builder-angular:application - build ssr only, disable ssr from serve
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Description

We are trying to migrate to use `@angular-devkit/build-angular:application` however due to the `ssr` triggering the SSR during `serve` is causing us issues

What we need to have is to be able to disable the ssr handling via vite (ng serve), but build the server only

- no output: SSR output e.g. `dist/server`
- no SSR server: no SSR from dev-server (through vite)

Using the following: **output + SSR server**
```json
"prerender": true,
"ssr": {}
```

Using the following: **no output + SSR server**
```json
"prerender": true,
"ssr": false
```

Using the following: **no output + no SSR server**
```json
"prerender": false,
"ssr": false
```

Just some more context - our SSR is handled via dotnet ATM and changing all the process its not very simple (and needs to work for local/prod). We pass metadata in order to boot up the angular app for configs etc... which we include via provider (and can change dynamically/per request can have different configs e.g. by locale)


### Describe the solution you'd like

Some configuration along these lines

#### via serve opts
```json
"serve": {
  "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:dev-server",
  "options": {
    "disableSsr": true
  }
},
```

#### OR via build
```json
"build": {
  "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:application",
  "options": {
    ...
    "prerender": true,
    "ssr": {
        "devServer": false
    }
  },
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Some workarounds

- keep using `"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:dev-server"` (not sure if theres a new version for this)
- and for the client use either:
    -  `"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:application"` and disable `ssr+prerendering`
    - or `"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild"`

Issues.Title: Support where *browser* static assets (js,css,assets) are pulled from
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

Right now, we're running to a lot of "Chunk loading errors" when using CI/CD with Angular and Angular's SSR. The reason for this is because our CDN reaches out to origin to get static assets, which are served from SSR. As soon as a new build goes out, the CDN is cleared, and the new assets are now live.

This causes issues with people currently on the site as lazy-loaded chunks that are still wanting to be requested in the users browser will try to go back to origin, only for the CDN to find out they no longer exists because chunk file hashes changed, and trigger the "Chunk loading errors" we're constantly seeing.

In order for users to fix this, they must do a hard-refresh, something we do not want our users to have to go through, especially since we're an international company and at any point in time, we can have people millions of people on in any of our regions.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like to be able to configure where **browser** static assets are pulled. One solution we thought of is to be able to change the URL where browser assets are pulled from. Think of it like this:

1.) Build 5000 triggers. We somehow prefix in the CLI that **browser ** assets should be loaded from `https://my.cdn.com/5000/`. We then upload all the browser assets from the build to the `/5000` directory in our CDN.
2.) Build 5001 triggers. We somehow prefix in the CLI that **browser ** assets should be loaded from `https://my.cdn.com/5001/`. We then upload all the browser assets from the build to the `/5000` directory in our CDN.

If user was currently on 5000, the static assets from the `/5000` folder can still be loaded from our domain. If the user refreshes, and we had cleared our CDN, they would start getting `/5001` requests because the main html changed.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

As it stands right now, we're thinking about just doing a find and replace on any `./chunk` string in the output dist for `/browser` and doing this ourselves. I'm not sure if the Google team has ran into this, I'm sure they have, but I would also welcome any other solutions you guys come up with. The easiest though, would be to allow us to configure this somehow so that server assets always load locally, but browser assets can be changed where you serve them from.

Issues.Body:
The Angular CLI will now enable the Node.js compile cache when available for use. Node.js v22.8 and higher currently provide support for this feature. The compile cache stores the v8 intermediate forms of JavaScript code for the Angular CLI itself. This provides a speed up to initialization on subsequent uses the Angular CLI. The Node.js cache is stored in a temporary directory in a globally accessible location so that all Node.js instances of a compatible version can share the cache. The code cache can be disabled if preferred via `NODE_DISABLE_COMPILE_CACHE=1`.

Based on initial profiling, this change provides an ~6% production build time improvement for a newly generated project once the cache is available.

```

  Time (mean ± σ):      2.617 s ±  0.016 s    [User: 3.795 s, System: 1.284 s]

  Range (min … max):    2.454 s …  2.510 s    10 runs

Summary
```

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/build): introduce `outputMode` option to the application builder
Issues.Body:
The `outputMode` option defines the build output target, offering two modes:
- `'static'`: Generates a static site suitable for deployment on any static hosting service. This mode can produce a fully client-side rendered (CSR) or static site generated (SSG) site. When SSG is enabled, redirects are handled using the `<meta>` tag.
- `'server'`: Produces an application designed for deployment on a server that supports server-side rendering (SSR) or a hybrid approach.

Additionally, the `outputMode` option determines whether the new API is used. If enabled, it bundles the `server.ts` as a separate entry point, preventing it from directly referencing `main.server.ts` and excluding it from localization.

In the future, it is also being considered that this option will replace `appShell` and `prerendering` when server routing configuration is present.

Issues.Title: bug(Autocomplete): 'Selected' item is visually unset, even with the underlying control matching an option, due to filter editing
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

It is possible to have an autocomplete where the current value of the underlying control value matches an option that is being displayed - but that option is not marked as selected.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ec22ecc4-e027-4454-8d79-ebb3cda3d46f)

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link:  https://stackblitz.com/edit/qdwgu9?file=package.json (an unmodified fork of the 'Require an autocomplete option to be selected' demo of autocomplete as on https://material.angular.io/components/autocomplete/examples)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the autocomplete and select 'One'
2. ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/65d9ab91-0695-4be0-af55-1eae5eb65060)
3. Delete out the 'n' & the 'e' to be left with a filter of 'O'; note that the 'myControl.value' is still `One` (due to having set `requireSelection`)
4. ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3c45088e-c38b-401a-ad4e-8d731fa00b20)
5. Delete out the final 'O' from your filter; note that 'myControl.value' is again still `One`
6. ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ec22ecc4-e027-4454-8d79-ebb3cda3d46f)
7. In this context even though `myControl.value` is still `One` and `One` *is* visible in the list of options it is no longer marked as selected




### Expected Behavior

I would expect that when `myControl.value` matches a displayed option that option should be marked as selected. At least when `requireSelection=true`. 

For `requireSelection=false` I would expect one of two options. Either it should snapshot the `myControl.value` on `open` for purposes of 'selected marking'; as is done for `requireSelection=true`. Or it should just update 'selected' according to the actual exact value of the underlying control. Overall the latter seems more in line with what is likely actually wanted (as the model *is* that option at that particular point in time). 

### Actual Behavior

As soon as the filter was reduced down to `''` (empty string) the 'selected' value ui markings are removed. 
This same behavior also occurs if you add to your filter string to no longer include your element of selection in the options list and then revert to something that does. (Ie a filter of `One` -> `Onex` -> `One` will have caused your 'selected' element to have been unset)

Once removed the 'selected' highlight and checkmark in the ui seems to ONLY be able to fixed by reselecting an element.

There seem to be several related bugs such as
[selection indicator broken with mat-optgroup ](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/29189)
[updates to the control not being reflected in selection indicators](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/27861)
[initial form control values are not reflected on selection indicators](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/29422)

This ticket is specifically about the causing the selection indicator ui to fail based on the editing of the filter but it seems likely that the same underlying library fix may apply to many if not all of these other tickets.

### My current workarround
I am identifying the option I want 'selected' 'manually' and styling it appropriately. If you go this route make sure to set `hideSingleSelectorIndicator` to true as you do not want to deal with library provided checkmark that sometimes (but not always) shows up.


### Environment

- Angular: 18.2.2
- CDK/Material: 18.2.2
- Browser(s): Chrome 126.0.6478.183
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs

Issues.Title: bug(MatMenu): Memory Leak in MatMenu and MatAutocomplete
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

There are detached elements in memory snapshot after clicking the menu or autocomplete to show the dropdowns. It can be replicated in https://material.angular.io web site.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://material.angular.io/components/menu/overview menu component page. 
2. Click a menu to show the drop down. Then click the API tab to destroy the menu component. Repeat this steps several times.
3. Go to landing page. The menu-related memory should've been destroyed.
4. Take a memory snapshot.

Do similar steps to reproduce memory leak for Autocomplete.

### Expected Behavior

There should be no memory allocation related to MatMenu or MatAutocomplete because the landing page doesn't have them.

### Actual Behavior

There are many detached elemets that should've been garbage collected.
